user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fast_simple_hash:
```c
static uint32_t
fast_simple_hash (const uint8_t *data,
                  size_t data_size)
{
  uint32_t hash;

  if (0 != data_size)
  {
    size_t i;
    hash = data[0];
    for (i = 1; i < data_size; i++)
      hash = _MHD_ROTL32 (hash, 7) ^ data[i];
  }
  else
    hash = 0;

  return hash;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function fast_simple_hash:
static size_t
get_nonce_nc_idx (size_t arr_size,
                  const char *nonce,
                  size_t noncelen)
{
  mhd_assert (0 != arr_size);
  mhd_assert (0 != noncelen);
  return fast_simple_hash ((const uint8_t *) nonce, noncelen) % arr_size;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided target function fast_simple_hash and the related get_nonce_nc_idx. Neither contains any call to the Standard Library function memcmp, nor any other direct comparison of null-terminated C-strings using memory-comparison functions. fast_simple_hash operates on a byte buffer with an explicit data_size parameter (not a NUL-terminated string), and get_nonce_nc_idx passes an explicit length (noncelen) when calling the hash. There are no memcmp calls or implicit string comparisons in the supplied code fragments, so there are no code fragments that need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in this input.
